content.raw:
This mechanism adds spring damper forces to an existing joint.  So to model series elastic elements, I suppose one could construct an actuating joint and an elastic joint in series.  For example:
~~~
<model name="se_test_model">
  <link name="robot_base_body"/>
  <link name="actuated_piston"/>
  <link name="output_body"/>
  <joint name="motor_joint" type="prismatic">
    <parent>robot_base_body</parent>
    <child>actuated_piston</child>
  </joint>
  <joint name="elastic_joint" type="prismatic">
    <parent>actuated_piston</parent>
    <child>output_body</child>
    <axis>
      <stiffness>[series elastic element stiffness]</stiffness>
    </axis>
  </joint>
</model>
~~~
Where an actuating force(torque) can be applied on the `motor_joint` and the output forces are filtered through the `elastic_joint`.  Is that something you had in mind?

This mechanism adds spring damper forces to an existing joint. So to model series elastic elements, I suppose one could construct an actuating joint and an elastic joint in series. For example:

<model name="se_test_model">
  <link name="robot_base_body"/>
  <link name="actuated_piston"/>
  <link name="output_body"/>
  <joint name="motor_joint" type="prismatic">
    <parent>robot_base_body</parent>
    <child>actuated_piston</child>
  </joint>
  <joint name="elastic_joint" type="prismatic">
    <parent>actuated_piston</parent>
    <child>output_body</child>
    <axis>
      <stiffness>[series elastic element stiffness]</stiffness>
    </axis>
  </joint>
</model>

Where an actuating force(torque) can be applied on the motor_joint and the output forces are filtered through the elastic_joint. Is that something you had in mind?
